'Coumarin' (; 2H-chromen-2-one) is a fragrant organic chemical compound in the
benzopyrone chemical class, which is a colorless crystalline substance in its
standard state. It is found naturally in many plants, notably in high
concentration in the tonka bean (Dipteryx odorata), vanilla grass (Anthoxanthum
odoratum), sweet woodruff (Galium odoratum), mullein (Verbascum spp.), sweet
grass (Hierochloe odorata), cassia cinnamon (Cinnamomum cassia), sweet-clover
(Melilotus ssp.), and deertongue (Dichanthelium clandestinum). The name comes
from a French term for the tonka bean, coumarou. It has a sweet odor, readily
recognised as the scent of new-mown hay, and has been used in perfumes since
1882. Sweet woodruff, sweet grass and sweet-clover in particular are named for
their sweet smell, which in turn is due to their high content of this substance.
When it occurs in high concentrations in forage plants, coumarin is a somewhat
bitter-tasting appetite suppressant, and is presumed to be produced by plants as
a defense chemical in order to discourage predation.

Coumarin has been used as an aroma enhancer in pipe tobaccos and certain
alcoholic drinks, although in general it is banned as a flavorant food additive,
due to concerns regarding its hepatotoxicity in animal models.

Although coumarin itself has no anticoagulant properties, it is transformed into
the natural anticoagulant dicoumarol by a number of species of fungi. This
occurs as the result of the production of 4-hydroxycoumarin, then further (in
the presence of naturally occurring formaldehyde) into the actual anticoagulant
dicoumarol, a fermentation product and mycotoxin. This substance was responsible
for the bleeding disease known historically as "sweet clover disease" in cattle
eating moldy sweet clover silage. Bye, A. and H. K. King. 1970. The
biosynthesis of 4-hydroxycoumarin and dicoumarol by Aspergillus fumigatus
Fresenius. Biochemical Journal 117, 237-45.

Coumarin is used in the pharmaceutical industry as a precursor molecule in the
synthesis of a number of synthetic anticoagulant pharmaceuticals similar to
dicoumarol, the notable ones being warfarin (brand name Coumadin) and some even
more potent rodenticides that work by the same anticoagulant mechanism.
Coumarins are a type of vitamin K antagonists. Pharmaceutical coumarins were all
developed from the study of sweet clover disease.

Coumarin has clinical medical value by itself, as an edema modifier. Coumarin
and other benzopyrones, such as 5,6-benzopyrone, 1,2-benzopyrone, diosmin, and
others, are known to stimulate macrophages to degrade extracellular albumen,
allowing faster resorption of edematous fluids. Casley-Smith, J. R., et
al. (1993). [http://content.nejm.org/cgi/content/full/329/16/1158 Treatment of
lymphedema of the arms and legs with 5,6-benzo-(alpha)-pyrone.] NEJM 329(16)
1158â63. [http://www.lymphoedema.org.au/bp.html Review of
benzypyrone drugs and edema.] Lymphoedema.org Other biological
activities that may lead to other medical uses have been suggested, with
varying degrees of evidence.

Coumarin is also used as a gain medium in some dye lasers, SchÃ¤fer, F. P.
(Ed.). Dye Lasers, 3rd Ed. Berlin, Springer-Verlag. 1990. Duarte, F.
J. and L. W. Hillman (Eds.). Dye Laser Principles. New York, Academic.
1990. Duarte, F. J. Tunable Laser Optics. New York, Elsevier-Academic.
2003. Appendix of Laser Dyes. and as a sensitizer in older photovoltaic
technologies. U.S. Pat. No. 4175982 to Loutfy et al, issued Nov 27 1978 to
Xerox Corp.

Coumarin was first isolated in 1820 by A. Vogel of Munich, who initially mistook
it for benzoic acid. See: *Vogel, A. (1820). Darstellung von BenzoesÃ¤ure aus
der Tonka-Bohne und aus den Meliloten - oder Steinklee - Blumen (Preparation of
benzoic acid from tonka beans and from the flowers of melilot or sweet clover).
Annalen der Physik 64(2) 161-66. *Vogel, A. (1820). De l'existence de l'acide
bezoÃ¯que dans la feve de tonka et dans les fleurs de mÃ©lilot (On the existence
of benzoic acid in the tonka bean and in the flowers of melilot). Journal de
Pharmacie 6 305-09. [http://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/bpt6k78140v/f311.image
pages 307-08]. Also in 1820, Nicholas Jean Baptiste Gaston Guibourt (1790-
1867) of France independently isolated coumarin, but he realized that it was not
benzoic acid. Guibourt, N. J. B. G. Histoire AbrÃ©gÃ©e des Droques Simples
(Abridged History of Simple Drugs). Volume 2. Paris, L. Colas. 1820.
[http://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id=ucm.5324210081#view=1up;seq=166 pages 160-
161]. In a subsequent essay he presented to the pharmacy section of
l'AcadÃ©mie royale de MÃ©decine, Guibourt named the new substance
"coumarine". See:
*  Journal de Chimie MÃ©dicale, de Pharmacie et de Toxicologie, '1' :
   [http://books.google.com/books?id=L_IwAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA303#v=onepage&q&f=false
   303] (1825): "â¦ plus rÃ©cemment, dans un essai de nomenclature chimique, lu Ã 
   la section of Pharmacie de l'AcadÃ©mie royale de MÃ©decine, il l'a dÃ©signÃ©e
   sous le nom de coumarine, tirÃ© du nom du vÃ©gÃ©tal coumarouna odorata â¦" (â¦
   more recently, in an essay on chemical nomenclature, [which was] read to the
   pharmacy section of the Royal Academy of Medicine, he [Guibourt] designated
   it by the name "coumarine", derived from the name of the vegetable Coumarouna
   odorata â¦).
* Guibourt, N. J. B. G. Histoire Naturelle des Drogues Simples, ... , 6th ed.
  Paris, J. B. BailliÃ¨re et fils. 1869.
  [http://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/bpt6k5810074h/f378.image.langEN bottom of
  page 377]: "â¦ la matiÃ¨re cristalline de la fÃ¨ve tonka (matiÃ¨re que j'ai nommÃ©e
  coumarine) â¦" (â¦ the crystaline matter of the tonka bean (matter that I named
  coumarine â¦). In 1835, the French pharmacist A. Guillemette proved that
  Vogel and Guibourt had isolated the same substance. Guillemette, A. (1835)
  [http://books.google.com/books?id=vMJhd3_lpnkC&pg=PA172#v=onepage&q&f=false
  Recherches sur la matiÃ¨re cristalline du mÃ©lilot] (Research into the
  crystalline material of melilot). Journal de Pharmacie 21 172-78.
  Coumarin was first synthesized in 1868 by the English chemist William Henry
  Perkin. Perkin, W. H. (1868).
  [http://books.google.com/books?id=ETrPAAAAMAAJ&pg=PA53#v=onepage&q&f=false On
  the artificial production of coumarin and formation of its homologues.]
  Journal of the Chemical Society 21 53-63.
